moves.1. e4: Here's an interesting win from one of 4 games I've just finished against this opponent (two league, two tournament).  We finished 2-2 and this was the jammiest win:-)
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Bc5: An interesting variation wherein Black's dsb adopts a more aggressive posture than in the Morphy Defence (4. ...Nf6, 5....d6, 6....Be7), aiming at White's vulnerable f2 square
moves.5. O-O Nf6 6. d3: I adopt a conservative approach, supporting the e4 pawn with my d-pawn rather than with Re1, which leaves f2 poorly defended.  This approach makes White's normally slow Spanish Torture even slower.
moves.6... h6: Presumably to prevent Bg5, a common enough prophylactic move in the Spanish.
moves.7. c3: Creating an escape square for my lsb and preparing an eventual d4
moves.7... b5: Standard approach to pushing White's B back and enabling development of Black's lsb to b7
moves.8. Bb3: As usual, I don't retreat my B all the way until I have to.  From b3 this B repays the compliment by attacking f7.
moves.8... d6: Creating other options for Black's lsb and freeing the Nc6 of its defensive duty in respect of e5.
moves.9. h3: To prevent the annoying 9...Bg4 and create a hole for the K
moves.9... Be6: Offering to exchange Bishops at the expense of doubled pawns in front of his K.  Such doubled pawns shouldn't be too weakening though because of the mobile d pawn and the resultant half-open f-file.
moves.10. Bxe6: I decided to accept the exchange as I couldn't see much future for my lsb after 10. Bc2 and I didn't want to allow him to exchange on b3.
moves.10... fxe6 11. Re1: Preparing to push the d-pawn, support the option of Be3 and create space for a potential knight manoeuvre Nbd2-f1-g3
moves.11... O-O 12. Nbd2 Nh5: Interesting... It creates an opportunity for White to reveal an attack on h5 by moving his knight.  Exactly how to take advantage of this exercised my mind for a while.  As we shall see, I miscalculated.  I can't take advantage of the opportunity immediately because moving my knight also allows ...Bxf2+, now that Black's R occupies the f-file.
moves.13... Bb6 14. d4 exd4 15. Nfxd4: Now I thought I could do it but ...
moves.15... Nxd4 16. Qxh5: ?  Missing the response.  I should have played 16. Nxd4
moves.17. Be3 Nxa1 18. Nxa1: Now, objectively, White must be losing, the exchange down with no compensatory assets, especailly after Black's next move.
moves.18... Bxe3: Exchanging down to accentuate the material advantage.
moves.19. Rxe3 d5 20. exd5 Qxd5: Offering to exchange Queens with the same motivation
moves.21. Qg4: White clings to a last chance: to deliver a mating attack on g7; also keeping d1 covered to avoid the fork of K and N and attacking e6 simultaneously.
moves.21... e5 22. Nc2: White's least mobile piece seeks to join the party
moves.23. Qg6: allowing the check on d1 but still defending the N on c2 and maintaining pressure on g7.  I'm aiming for Rg3 next, followed by Ne3 and Nf5
moves.23... e4 24. Nd4: As the defence of c2 had been cut off, I had to change my plan slightly
moves.24... c5 25. Ne6: forking the R on f4 and the pawn on g7
moves.25... Rf7: Black deals easily enough with those threats ...
moves.26... Raa7: Black has plenty enough defensive resources, it seems
moves.28. Nf4: in turn, threatening Black's Q and aiming for g6
moves.28... Qe5 29. Ng6: Now the pawn on g7 is no longer pinned but Black's Q and Ne7 are forked and mate is threatened on h8
